p.s: 1. The Au Viet and the Lac Viet.
In the sixth part of our series on Vietnam's history we look at the kingdom of the Au Viet and Lac Viet people and how they fought off the Chinese Qi'n dynasty troops in the third century AD.
Since its establishment, Van Lang was a kingdom incorporating various tribes (who were generally referred to as the ancient Viet)
The Lac Viet constituted the majority of Van Lang's population
They lived in highlands and lowlands of the Red river delta
The mountainous area north of the Van Lang kingdom was the living place of the Au Viet
In many places, the living place of the Au Viet and Lac Viet alternated
Both the Au and Lac were Viet people.
By that time, the Au Viet people were able to cast working tools and weapons of brass copper
They cultivated on hilly slopes, grew rice in lowlands, raised cattle and livestock, and fished in springs and rivers
Particularly, they were skilled at using bows and arrows and hunting
The Au Viet wore left-buttoned overalls like the Lac Viet.
The Lac Viet produced a lot of rice, pottery, pearls etc
They exchanged with the Au Viet for copper, tin, rhino and elephant horns and other products
The Au Viet were linked with the Lac Viet by close sentimental ties

The legend on the marriage of Lord Lac Long Quan and fairy Au Co, or the one between the Fish-boy with the Deer-girl of the Muong minority reflected the aged-old relation between the inhabitants in the highlands and those in the lowlands.
In late the third century BC, both the Lac Viet and the Au Viet were prospering
Metal working tools were improved; cultivated land was expanded and the population grew fast
However, the threat of invasion from the North was increasing.
By then, the Qi'n dynasty in China had been founded (221 BC)
In carrying out its expansion scheme, in 218 BC, Shih Huang-ti ordered a general to take 50 thousand troops which were divided into five armies to conquer the Bach Viet in the south
Wherever the Qi'n troops went through, they set up new districts and cantons
The invaders made deep advance into the land of the Au Viet and Lac Viet.
In face of the aggression of the Qi'n invaders, the Au Viet and Lac Viet got together to defend themselves
The Qi'n troops were very strong and stormy in their attack
The local people could not confront the invaders face-to-face, and they had to make a prolonged war of resistance
Leaving their homes, gardens and fields behind, they went deep in jungles or up to high mountains taking with them only food, weapons and cattle
Old and young, male and female people joined in discussing strategy and they made the best among them generals to lead the resistance
Thuc Phan, the chief of the then Au Viet was a young, bold and intelligent man
He was chosen to lead the army
His troops hid themselves in the daytime and when the night came, they launched surprise attacks on the enemies
The Qi'n troops encamped in deserted villages and hamlets where they could not plunder any food of the locals and were frequently ambushed and skirmished.
China's old history describes that the Qi'n troops "...were at dilemma whether to advance nor retreat
Men had to put on armour all year round and women had to carry supplies all day who found their life like in hell..."
The resistance of the Viet people against the Qi'n troops went on and on for years
Tens of thousands of invaders were killed and enemy general Tu' Shu also lost his life

When emperor Qi'n Shui Huang was dead the Chinese people rose up in revolts everywhere, and the Qi'n had to withdraw their invasion troops back home (208 BC) 2. The Au Lac Kingdom founded by Thuc Phan.
Defeating the Qi'n invaders, Thuc Phan incorporated all lands into Van Lang and founded the Lac Viet kingdom
He ascended the throne taking the royal title An Duong Vuong (Thuc An Duong Vuong).
At first, An Duong Vuong located the capital in Phong Chau, Bach Hac, Phu Tho
Later, he decided to move the capital to Co Loa, a high area in the basin of the Red River delta which belongs to the present-day suburban district of Dong Anh, Hanoi.
Co Loa was called Cha Chu at that time
It was located in a high, populated area with good sight-lines around
The Hoang, a branch of the Red river took a zigzag course through the southern part of Co Loa and connected with the Cau river
It was possible to go from the Hoang River to the Red River to go up to the north, or to go to the Cau river to go down to the East Sea.
